intro: Mallophyton chimantense, commonly known as the Chimanté grass, is a flowering plant native to the humid lowland forests of Ecuador. It belongs to the Poaceae family, which includes grasses, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and slender, wiry stems. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, typical of many grass species. It thrives in shaded, moist environments and plays a role in maintaining soil stability in its native habitat. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and potentially endangered species.
